summary: This document is an email chain between Jeffrey Goldberg, an Amazon.com attorney, and a prosecutor's office regarding a grand jury subpoena (CRIM1031692) issued to Amazon. The discussion centers on Amazon's legal concerns about producing customer records related to 'expressive materials' (e.g., book purchases) due to First Amendment protections, citing relevant case law. The context indicates the subpoena is part of a criminal investigation, likely related to Jeffrey Epstein, as his death is mentioned as a factor.

persons.name: Jeffrey Goldberg
persons.role: Associate General Counsel, Litigation & Regulatory at Amazon.com Inc.
persons.context: Amazon's attorney corresponding with prosecutors regarding a grand jury subpoena (CRIM1031692), raising First Amendment concerns about producing customer records related to 'expressive materials'.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as 'Mr. Epstein'; his death is noted as a factor potentially affecting the First Amendment considerations related to the subpoena for records.

connections.description: Goldberg, representing Amazon, is in communication with prosecutors regarding compliance with a grand jury subpoena, discussing legal objections and scheduling calls.
Goldberg is responding to a subpoena likely related to an investigation involving Epstein, as Epstein's death is mentioned in the context of the legal issues.

events.title: Grand Jury Subpoena CRIM1031692 Issued to Amazon
events.description: A grand jury subpoena was issued to Amazon.com as part of a criminal investigation, seeking records related to accounts and shipments associated with specific addresses, likely connected to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Email Correspondence on Subpoena Compliance
events.description: Email chain finalizing a call scheduled for Monday regarding Amazon's legal position on the subpoena, focusing on First Amendment protections for customer 'expressive materials'.

locations: Seattle, WA 98121 (Amazon.com Inc. office at 2021 7th Avenue)

keyFacts: Amazon's legal team, led by Jeffrey Goldberg, was actively negotiating compliance with a grand jury subpoena (CRIM1031692) related to a criminal investigation, likely involving Jeffrey Epstein.

Amazon raised significant First Amendment objections, citing case law that requires a heightened showing of relevance and need before compelling production of records related to 'expressive materials' like book purchases.
Jeffrey Epstein's death was mentioned as a factor that might affect whether First Amendment privacy interests were still 'active' in the investigation.
The subpoena sought records for accounts associated with specific addresses, and Amazon expressed concerns about the request's overbreadth while agreeing to preserve responsive information.
Amazon indicated a willingness to file a motion to quash the subpoena if necessary, preferring a stipulated briefing schedule with the prosecution.
